description: Test scenario for interdisciplinary research combining computational and qualitative methods

ThesisContext.title: Algorithmic Governance and Democratic Legitimacy: A Mixed-Methods Investigation of Automated Decision-Making in Public Administration
research_questions: How do algorithmic decision-making systems reshape bureaucratic discretion and accountability in public administration?
What are the lived experiences of frontline workers navigating algorithmic recommendations in welfare determination?
Can computational auditing methods detect and quantify bias in deployed public sector algorithms?
contributions: A theoretical framework integrating science and technology studies (STS) with public administration theory
Qualitative study (n=45 interviews, 200 hours of observation) of algorithmic implementation in three welfare agencies
Open-source auditing toolkit for bias detection in rule-based and ML-based decision systems
Policy recommendations for algorithmic accountability adopted by two national governments

terminology_glossary.definition: The use of computational systems to make, inform, or implement governmental decisions
The latitude officials have in interpreting and applying rules to individual cases
Mechanisms ensuring algorithmic systems are transparent, fair, and subject to redress
Systematic examination of algorithmic systems using computational methods to detect bias or errors
Research approach integrating quantitative and qualitative data collection and analysis
Public service workers who interact directly with citizens and exercise discretion in policy implementation

tense_rules.results: past for qualitative findings, present for analysis

must_include: integration of qualitative and quantitative approaches
ethical considerations for both human subjects and algorithmic research
must_not_include: privileging one methodological tradition over another
technical jargon without explanation for non-specialist readers

methodology_writer.integration: must explain how methods complement each other

lit_review_writer.cross_disciplinary: must bridge computer science and social science literatures
